item.title: [New Preprint] Intrinsic decoherence dynamics in the three-coupled harmonic oscillators interaction
item.description: Some time ago I put an idea on the decoherence drive on a coupled system of three interacting quantum harmonic oscillators, this works is in collaboration with Dr. Héctro M. Moya-Cessa. Now, we have submitted the full paper on the arXiv preprint server, and a mirror on ResearchGate. Intrinsic decoherence dynamics in the three-coupled harmonic oscillators interaction Alejandro R. Urzúa, Héctor M. Moya-Cessa [arXiv] [ResearchGate] Abstract: Applying the Milburn equation to describe intrinsic decoherence, we study the interaction of three-coupled quantum harmonic oscillators or quantized fields.

item.title: When zero-coefficients don't lead the recursions terms
item.description: Imagine you have a three-term recursion like this one $$ g_{k+1} = A(l,k) g_{k} + B(l,k) g_{k-1},$$ where the \(g\)’s are items of the recursion, and \(A(l, k)\) and \(B(l, k)\) are coefficients who depends on some parameter \(l\) at index \(k\). When we compute the recursion, the algorithm expects that the previous items are already calculated, but imagine this g[1] = "some initial function" for k in 1:N g[k + 1] = A(l,k) g[k] + B(l,k) g[k - 1] end where we don’t know the value of g[(k = 1) - 1] = g[0].

item.title: A seemly definition of the Kravchuk function on JuliaLang
item.description: Intro I’ve been used Julia on a daily basis for almost a year. Since the start one of my purposes was to get the Kravchuk function \(\Phi_{n}^{(j)}(q) \) correctly for at least 64 points, that is \(j = 32\). Since I came from Python and there the mpmath returns Hypergeometric functions without hesitation, I look for some like this in Julia. HypergeometricFunctions.jl is the (only?) package to bring the hyperthing \(_2F_1\).

item.title: Intrinsic decoherence in the three-mode coupled harmonic oscillators
item.description: Idea: A three-mode coupled harmonic oscillators have a Hamiltonian in the form $$(1)\qquad\hat{H} = \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{i = 1}^{3}\hat{p}_{k}^{2} + \sum\limits_{j<k}^{3}g_{j,k}\hspace{5px} \hat{q}_{j}\hat{q}_{k},$$ where the coupling strengths \(g_{j,k}\) are time-independent. Now, there exist a framework1 for ripping off the non-diagonal terms in (1) by performing an angle-dependent unitary transformation \(\hat{T}(\theta_{j,k})\). Given that last, we can address the problem to calculate the intrinsic decoherence of the system for the master equation $$(2)\qquad \dot{\rho} = -\mathrm{i}\left[\hat{H},\rho\right] + 2\gamma\left(2\hat{H}\rho\hat{H} - \hat{H}^{2}\rho - \rho\hat{H}^{2}\right),$$

item.title: Finding classical deaths and revivals, like in the atom-field interaction?
item.description: Maybe it’s a tricky task to put a link between the diametrical phenomenology of classical and quantum mechanics; but, for the most of the history, we use the first as an archetype to extend the comprehension of the second. Working around a superb-classical system, like a set of \(N\) coupled harmonic oscillators $$(1)\qquad \ddot{q_{i}}(t) = -(k_{i} + k_{i+1})q_{i}(t) + k_{i+1}q_{i+1}(t) + k_{i}q_{i-1}(t),$$ we can solve the set of equation with a plethora of methods developed in the last centuries.
